1.text:
[applause]
Ladies and gentlemen, from EE, please welcome

2.text:
the head of customer technology & innovation,
and customer service, David Walker.

14.text: Good afternoon, I think it's just me standing

17.text:
between you and your lunch now so hopefully
you will find this interesting. It's the story

22.text:
of our journey of knowledge transformation
with eGain in EE. First I want to start with

31.text:
a little bit of context around what is EE,
for those of you guys who don't know, and

38.text:
a little bit about customer service. It just
gives you a bit of an idea of scale that we

42.text:
have done the transformation on. So firstly,
we're the biggest and fastest network in the

49.text:
UK. We are now part of the BT Group which
is the largest and most advanced digital communication

56.text:
company in Britain, delivering mobile and
fixed communications. We have around 550 retail

63.text:
stores and service more than 31 million connections
across mobile and fixed networks. EE runs

71.text:
the UK's biggest and fastest mobile network,
pioneering the UK's first, super-fast 4G mobile

78.text:
service in October 2012. We are the first
European operator to surpass the 14 million

85.text:
4G customer landmark. EE's 4G coverage today
reaches more than 95% of the UK population,

95.text:
with unique, double-speed 4G reaching 75%.
EE's 2G coverage reaches 99% of the population

103.text:
and 3G coverage reaches 98%. EE's super-fast
fiber broadband covers around 80% of the UK

110.text:
population and ADSL 98.7%. A brief history
of EE, it all started off in Bristol and Borehamwood.

120.text:
EE was formed in 2010 following the merger
of Orange and T-Mobile, at that point in time

125.text:
we were called Everything, Everywhere. T-Mobile
began as Mercury one2one founded in Borehamwood

132.text:
in the early 90s and then rebranded to one2one
before being purchased by Deutsche Telecom

139.text:
in 1999 and re-branding to T-Mobile. Orange
was founded in Bristol in 1996 and became

146.text:
the youngest ever company to enter the FTSE
100. It was acquired by France Telecom in

151.text:
2000 and bought Wanadoo to add fixed broadband
alongside the mobile offering. We're investing

159.text:
more than 15B building Britain’s biggest
network. Just a couple of stats, we are UK's

169.text:
first 4G. We have 4G in more than 600 cities
& large towns and more that 6000 small towns

176.text:
& villages with 95%+ population coverage.
We are expanding 4G coverage by around 2000

183.text:
square miles each month and have more than
14 million 4G customers. We have the UK's

190.text:
biggest 3G network also and we are continuing
to invest and grow month per month. A little

198.text:
bit about customer service now, we have 6
in-house sites dotted around the UK. We have

204.text:
partners in the UK, Ireland, and India and
we have around 10 thousand advisors. 80% of

210.text:
those are within the UK & Ireland with the
remaining 20% in India. Let's move on to the

217.text:
really interesting topic which is customer
service transformation with eGain knowledge.

223.text:
I'm going to run you through the challenge,
so why did we do it? What was the reason we

229.text:
embarked on this journey? Second, what we
did & what we delivered. Third, what results

235.text:
have we seen? I've got some results to share
with you on the success we've seen. What we

240.text:
learned and what's next. So to get started,
the first challenge we had was we had a huge

250.text:
variation in performance. We looked at that
and why we were getting such a variance because

257.text:
performance is a mixture of people & process.
Is it the people delivering great service

262.text:
regardless of the process or is it the process
delivering great service regardless of the

268.text:
person? That's to say when we looked at range
in performance we had huge variance on customer

274.text:
satisfaction. We had huge variance on handle
time of calls, we had huge variance on answers

281.text:
given to customers. We had a little bit of
a problem because customers were calling us

285.text:
back to check if what we have said was correct.
Because of the variance you sometimes would

291.text:
get a different answer when you phoned in.
So you could ring in three times and get three

295.text:
different results, which isn't great because
there is only one right answer generally for

301.text:
these things. What we found, and this was
really helpful later, was our best people

307.text:
could crack it. So our best agents were absolutely
bringing the numbers in with the right handle-time

313.text:
and delivering a great customer experience.
We used this later on in the story as I continue

319.text:
through because using that knowledge we got
from the best agents really helped to create

324.text:
really compelling content to look through.
The second challenge was, as I said the journey

333.text:
where we've gone through T-Mobile & Orange
combining, we had four knowledge tools. We

339.text:
had a T-Mobile knowledge tool, we had an Orange
knowledge tool, we did diagnosis in Orange,

345.text:
and we had also introduced a fourth tool to
add to that. All of these tools were based

352.text:
around searching predominately with the exception
of the diagnostics. What we found when we

359.text:
measured it was we were getting around 10%
consistent use of knowledge. So our advisors

366.text:
were using knowledge correctly and accurately
and consistently around 10% of the time. The

373.text:
knowledge information was inconsistent so
when we crossed the different systems, the

378.text:
same process might have a number of different
instructions. We were using tick sheets to

384.text:
capture contact reasons and we found those,
I don't know if you guys found the same, pretty

389.text:
problematic. Years ago, we thought we had
a major problem with the answer phone. Just

394.text:
so happens it was at the top of the list of
the selected reasons. So we were worrying

399.text:
about that and in reality that wasn't the
case at all. We had, believe it or not, over

405.text:
20,000 articles across the knowledge base.
Now when I first started we had a flip chart

413.text:
on the desk that had twenty pages in, with
all of the help and knowledge you need. Now

420.text:
20,000 articles, if you printed those out
and taped them together you can hang them

424.text:
from top of Big Ben, you can hang them on
the BT Tower, you can hang them on Tower Bridge.

430.text:
Before you got arrested for doing that, essentially.
It's massive, it's absolutely massive. It's

437.text:
completely where technology comes in and helps
us here. Why did we choose eGain? Obviously

445.text:
we went through a RFP process as we would
normally do. The key reasons for eGain: Number

451.text:
one, it had the capabilities we wanted to
drive us forward. Secondly, we really felt

457.text:
the eGain team had a desire to work with us
and help us realize our ambition. Thirdly,

464.text:
to collaborate as we grow. This isn't a journey
that we want to stop, we want to continue

469.text:
with [it]. So we wanted some collaboration
with that, on the route. That's what we feel

476.text:
eGain brings to the table. What we did and
what we delivered next. So we got the inspiration

487.text:
from the NHS and the processes they use on
the grounds that we cannot afford to get it

492.text:
wrong. We had a real problem with getting
it wrong and we absolutely wanted to crack

498.text:
that problem. We looked at what other organizations,
such as NHS, were doing to actually get it

505.text:
right. Like most things, I don’t know if
you guys do the same, but we have a habit

512.text:
of naming systems and our advisors love to
be part of that process as well. We called

518.text:
it Albert, no abbreviation for anything it
is after Albert Einstein because we felt it

524.text:
was real expert knowledge in one place. The
key features we've implemented, summarized.

533.text:
We pass in customer and device information
into the knowledge. We give the advisors the

540.text:
ability to pause and resume sessions. We do
this so that if we need to break a process

545.text:
with a customer, so we need them to stop and
go away and do something, we can allow them

550.text:
to do that and come back without having to
start explaining things again which was a

554.text:
problem we had previously. We also save the
guided help session into our CRM system so

561.text:
anyone across the company, wider than customer
service, can see what has happened there.

568.text:
This is a quick shot of the system as the
advisor lands on it. There is a step before

576.text:
this where the advisor puts the phone number
into a system we call Toolkit that our IT

581.text:
teams developed and then they are launched
into ALBERT. What that does is that it transfers

586.text:
the customer's information into the knowledge
system and we start a journey there. There

591.text:
are a number of different sections you know,
customer service, billing, network. It's the

596.text:
primary issue the customer is ringing about
initially that we go through. As I mentioned,

604.text:
pre-answering questions is really important
because we use it for two purposes. Number

609.text:
one, it helps us minimize the number of questions
we need to ask our customers. Our customers

614.text:
think we are daft if we keep asking them things
that we already know about them. The second

619.text:
reason, it's really useful for reporting at
the end because we've got a snapshot in time

623.text:
of some key information there. What plan is
the customer on, what is the balance, those

627.text:
sort of things. That becomes super helpful
later, which we will go through. What we present

634.text:
to the advisors is pretty much a three column
screen. The first column, quite a dry example

641.text:
here but nothing contentious in it. The first
column is the question. There are two or more

649.text:
answers to the question and the advisor goes
through and answers a series of questions

654.text:
which drives, ultimately, to a resolution.
The second column is the advisor help. Now

661.text:
what we haven't done is we haven't taught
our advisors to work like robots and script

667.text:
everything. It was very important to us that
we didn't do that because it creates and unnatural

671.text:
flow of conversation. There are things at
times, such as regulatory information, that

676.text:
we need to read out to cover it often in which
case we do script it but predominately we

681.text:
give the advisor the ability to deliver great
customer service and give an engaging flow.

687.text:
What we have in there is some useful hints
and tips for the conversation. We also then

692.text:
help the guys how to do it in the system,
so the second bit, our CRM system is called

699.text:
Excalibur. The instructions are there on what
to do within the CRM and that's really helpful

705.text:
in terms of saving training time because you've
got what you need to do right on the screen

709.text:
there. We also cover any other useful hint
and anything else for the customer in that

714.text:
middle section. On the right-hand side, we
have some control buttons. Feedback I'll talk

723.text:
about in a moment. Restart, so if you've gone
completely down the wrong route you can start

728.text:
right back again and move through. We also
have what we call "Albert Breaking News."

734.text:
This isn't information on content, these are
things to add a little bit of context around

741.text:
it. We make sure that's visible all of the
time in case there is any relevant that comes

746.text:
up outside of the guided help. Onto feedback
now, what we've found really important is,

755.text:
it is absolutely imperative that we have the
content correct. It's really, really important

760.text:
on that and if there is something wrong we
need our advisors to tell us so we can fix

765.text:
it. I'll certainly review it and see whether
it is incorrect. So we have a feedback button

769.text:
on every page so if there is anything wrong
or anything needs improving on those articles,

775.text:
you simply hit the feedback button and that
feeds back through to our knowledge team.

780.text:
What our knowledge team do there, and we have
a very tight SLA on that so typically we will

786.text:
get back to an advisor within 24 hours. When
the advisor feeds the feedback in, that is

793.text:
reviewed by our content team and they make
a decision. Is it something that is in error

799.text:
in the content or is it something simply that
needs to be fixed or is it something that

802.text:
has changed recently that we haven't updated.
If it's a straightforward change, the content

807.text:
is updated and a response is sent back and
we start that cycle again. If it's a more

813.text:
complicated change that needs further review,
we hold sessions with a more senior audience

819.text:
and process teams to make sure we thoroughly
review it. Again, we don't want to get it

823.text:
wrong, it's vitally important we've got the
right information here. We find that really

828.text:
effective and the feedback loop is really
important because it encourages people to

832.text:
feed back. We get several hundred bits of
feedback a week of which 10-15% of those actually

839.text:
result in change, mostly it is for clarity
of information. On to what we delivered effectively

847.text:
through the rollout. We deployed the product
and we deployed the content and we trained

855.text:
over 10,000 advisors and three retail stores.
So we used this for customer service & retail.

866.text:
From a knowledge content perspective, from
our 20,000 individual articles to ten guided

874.text:
help case bases. Ten is not necessarily a
number you want to aim for but we've found

884.text:
is that it is the right balance in terms of
the number of case bases to set up. We did

889.text:
a complete overhaul and rewrite of our knowledge
content and set standards up for that. That

895.text:
ensures that we've got consistency in the
way it is presented and that really helps

899.text:
our front-line advisors. We have clear content
ownership and accountability. Previously we

906.text:
let the process teams write a lot of the content
but what we found is it wasn't particularly

912.text:
customer or advisor-savvy. We actually used
our best advisors to help us write this, back

919.text:
to that quartile slide, there are people there
that really know how to do it. They also know

924.text:
how to articulate it so if you share that
information you can make a huge difference.

931.text:
The accountability for knowledge was really
key here. The reason we had the challenge

937.text:
previously within consistency is accountability
had drifted off over time. We have a single

943.text:
knowledge content team for which we have a
core team and we bring in advisors to make

949.text:
sure we are fresh. The core team also spend
time on the phones because it is vastly important

955.text:
that we keep that knowledge fresh and keep
the people fresh to what's going on within

961.text:
the contact centers. We also now capture automated
contact reasons. We retired two, previously

969.text:
widely used, capture tools. All of this is
done automatically, there is no box to fill

975.text:
in, there is nothing to click, nothing to
get wrong, it is done as a part of the process.

981.text:
More on that in a little while. What we found.
In the frontline we found that first contact

991.text:
resolution had improved. We did a case study
to measure this specifically because we've

995.text:
done a lot of transformation and change at
the same time. As you guys know, it's quite

1000.text:
difficult sometimes to actually work out what
has driven what change. When guided help is

1006.text:
used correct we were measuring FCR on 85%
of calls. When it was not at all, the old

1014.text:
way, 62% so a huge increase there of 23%.
We found also that guided help contributed

1022.text:
to a 20% increase in net promoter score. We
measure, as we discussed earlier, customer

1028.text:
satisfaction. At the end of each call we send
them a text and use that to measure customer

1036.text:
satisfaction and we use NPS as one of the
methods for that. We've also seen complaints

1041.text:
reduced as a result of this. From a training
perspective, when we get new hire and new

1048.text:
intake, guided help has reduced our training
time from at least 14 working days down to

1055.text:
8. We've not compromised the training there,
we are just teaching the guys how to use the

1060.text:
system rather than cramming their heads with
processes, procedures, devices, and things

1065.text:
like that. We've lightened that up now because
all of the answers are in the guided help.

1070.text:
We've improved speed to competency, this is
the time from a new advisor joining to being

1077.text:
competent at serving customers effectively,
from six months, which was often extended,

1083.text:
down to three months. A 50% improvement there.
This has been huge in terms of training. We

1091.text:
found we had another problem then, we needed
to get our logins done much quicker because

1094.text:
we were getting people through training and
had to get our HR set up. It's interesting,

1099.text:
one problem fixed actually drives the next
opportunity. From a frontline perspective,

1108.text:
just to summarize what we saw. From a customer's
perspective, consistent information is given,

1115.text:
if you ring back up to check it's correct
you will get the same message. We have a better

1121.text:
customer experience as a result of that because
we are giving the right information at the

1126.text:
right time through a structured method. That
has really improved our customer service,

1130.text:
the results we covered a few minutes ago.
From a business perspective, we've improved

1137.text:
first contact resolution significantly. We've
aligned the handle time; we've moved from

1143.text:
massive variance in handle time. We've reduced
complaints, and we've reduced training. That

1152.text:
sounds a little bit negative "reduced training"
doesn't. it but we've made training much more

1156.text:
effective and made the people more effective
as a result. From an advisor perspective,

1163.text:
they have the knowledge at their fingertips
and their KPIs are achievable. If you follow

1168.text:
the guided help, you will succeed. Very straightforward.
Advisor confidence is much stronger because

1175.text:
we are not scrambling around trying to search
for things and hunting through the fourth

1179.text:
page of search results. We found search pretty
challenging from that perspective because

1184.text:
you really needed to know how to search and
you no longer need to. Beyond the front line,

1192.text:
this is probably the one that, personally
I thought we knew we were going to get this,

1198.text:
it was common sense this is what we were going
to get. Until you've actually got this data,

1203.text:
you don't realize how powerful it is. We use
the call reasons. So the agents follow the

1209.text:
guided help, the data gets transformed, we
attach some additional metrics to it, so it's

1214.text:
joining data together. We attach the call
center metrics, the satisfaction survey, etc.

1222.text:
Then we've got insights that answers to particular
problems. Number one, it gives businesses

1229.text:
awareness of call drivers which we didn't
have effectively previously. Secondly, people

1235.text:
and performance management to make sure we
can continually evolve and make sure the advisors

1241.text:
are working to best-in-class. We have company-wide
program and we focus on what we call "propensity

1252.text:
to contact" (PTC), The number of times a customer
contacts us each year. We effectively split

1258.text:
these into two categories, one is what does
customer service own, because that is our

1265.text:
problem to fix, and what other products, services,
and propositions that are business owned.

1273.text:
We do regular weekly tracking and we have
a company-wide program to actually drive these

1279.text:
initiatives and make sure we are making improvements
and to make sure we are making the right decisions

1283.text:
from a customer service perspective when we
are launching propositions. Previously our

1288.text:
marketers would have fantastic ideas but we
didn't always think through the customer service

1294.text:
element. The data that we get out of the back
of eGain joined with other information is

1302.text:
super powerful. We have clear accountability
for this and that's one theme we've had all

1307.text:
the way through from content to improvement.
It's all about real, clear accountability.

1315.text:
What we found through the drive to reduces
PTC, we grouped the call reasons into business

1324.text:
functions and tracked them weekly. Very frequent
tracking, very real-time information. Established

1331.text:
for each of those, the clear accountability
and ownership. We got 100% buy-in across the

1337.text:
business, we had top-down buy-in to make sure
that happened. People couldn't hide away anymore

1343.text:
if something happened, they had to follow-up
and fix things when we had any issues. They

1349.text:
key learning we found was, we had the most
successful period of reducing PTC following

1358.text:
implementation and making sure we had the
accountability because we had the tangible

1363.text:
data there to make it happen. That really
helped us from that perspective. We also allow

1373.text:
analysts across the business to deep dive
call reasons, so everyone can get under the

1379.text:
bonnet and see. Previously we did not have
this capability to do that. Now that we have

1385.text:
this rich information we can really get down
into the detail. You can see the difference

1391.text:
between particular handsets on performance
for example. We had a great piece come out

1397.text:
very early on this. We had picked up a variance
on performance with a certain handset from

1407.text:
a certain manufacturer. We pulled that out,
contacted the manufacturer and said text message

1411.text:
problems seem to be completely out of the
norm for your particular devices, it’s completely

1418.text:
different from what we are seeing across the
rest of the range. We fed that in and we also

1422.text:
fed in some insight that we got from it with
a little bit more detail. Within around a

1427.text:
week, that manufacturer had updated the software
on the handset, pushed it out to the customers,

1432.text:
and fixed the problem. You would never find
that previously because amid 40 million other

1439.text:
calls per year it's a needle-in-a-haystack,
we are talking a few hundred calls here and

1445.text:
you could find that data and that has been
super helpful. It allows you to pick things

1450.text:
up that you just wouldn't find previously.
We essentially week to week, month to month,

1459.text:
rank the call reason information that we get
out of eGain tied to the other data. We put

1466.text:
that in a league table to figure out what
we need to focus on to get the biggest impact

1471.text:
because you can’t change everything at once.
We break it down into the key things that

1476.text:
are going to give the biggest value return.
We cut that by first contact resolution and

1482.text:
customer satisfaction results and that helps
us prioritize our continuous improvement activity.

1491.text:
What we've done as well is we have linked
the contact reasons to the call recording.

1495.text:
Joining up the data gives you massively more
powerful information and we allow our agents,

1502.text:
our managers, and our quality teams to listen
to those call recordings. One of the key things

1508.text:
we did as well is we gave our advisors the
ability to listen to best practice calls.

1513.text:
So with the contact reasons now, we can pick
out calls that are really good quality in

1520.text:
a certain specifically complicated thing.
It might be a signal issue for example. Those

1527.text:
tend to be quite complicated processes because
there are a lot of variable in there but we

1531.text:
can actually demonstrate to the advisers what
good looks like. By joining data up it makes

1537.text:
a huge difference in what we can achieve there.
What we learned. These are the things we kind

1549.text:
of picked up that we weren't expecting as
we came through. First point was, as I mentioned

1556.text:
earlier we did a wide customer service transformation
program at the same time, one thing we did

1560.text:
as a part of that was implement dual screens.
Dual screens really helped us here in combination

1568.text:
with the knowledge transformation because
it allows the advisor to work on the left

1572.text:
or the right screen with the guided help,
walk through there, and execute the transactions

1579.text:
on the other screen. That was a really great
partnership with guided help to make that

1587.text:
work. Secondly, as you can probably see, reporting
was something that was really, really amazing.

1594.text:
We knew we were going to get it we just didn't
know how powerful this was going to be to

1598.text:
help us both within customer service and in
the larger organization. Completely transparent

1603.text:
reporting back to the advisors to ensure they
understand how they're performing. We have

1611.text:
a target of 90% guided help usage, which is
regularly exceeded. There are obviously odd

1618.text:
calls where it’s just a random call that
you wouldn't use it for but we set targets

1623.text:
there so we help the team managers and the
advisors ensure they are following that correctly.

1629.text:
The other thing we found and it was probably
a real biggie that we didn’t expect to be

1634.text:
such a challenge, we moved from search to
guided help and it was a huge cultural shift,

1640.text:
especially for our long serving advisors,
to move between search and guided help. It

1647.text:
did take quite a lot of work and there was
quite a lot of stick there to keep it moving

1650.text:
forward. What we did find when we measured
it, you could prove it statistically time

1656.text:
and time again, the people, long-term or new
starters, that were following guided help

1662.text:
had significantly better performance metrics
than those that didn't follow it correctly.

1668.text:
It kind of solved itself then using the metrics
back to the point above. The final point is,

1674.text:
IT resiliency. People who have been around
awhile still have quite a lot of knowledge

1680.text:
in their head but when we get into IT resiliency,
it's really important that if anything goes

1686.text:
wrong, if you mess up your content deployment
or anything like that, you've got some form

1692.text:
of standby that you can switch to because
the guys are flying blind if they lose the

1697.text:
system. Really, really important there to
make sure you've got the contingency in place

1703.text:
if anything does happen to go wrong. So what
next? This is our kind of logical next steps,

1714.text:
some of this is. So the first thing, I mentioned
earlier, we're really keen not to deploy something,

1719.text:
say hey this is great, and sit on it and effectively
not move it forward. Our current plan is we're

1727.text:
looking to upgrade to the latest version and
make sure that that's effective for us, we

1732.text:
exploit any new capabilities, and keep it
current. The second, how can we leverage guided

1740.text:
help for our customers. We've done some great
things within the contact center, the logical

1746.text:
next step is, how can we give that to our
customers and what will we need to do to do

1752.text:
that. So that's something we are really, really
super keen on at the moment. As I mentioned,

1757.text:
they key theme is let's keep current, let's
